content.title: Calle del Pez – surprises galore in this trendy Madrid street

introduction.small: In the heart of the trendy neighbourhood of Malasaña, Calle del Pez epitomises the Spanish capital's artistic explosion. The perfect place to wander around to your heart's content.

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of history

So, you have visited the unmissable Royal Palace, Plaza Mayor, the Prado museum and, of course, the Reina Sofía museum with Picasso's iconic masterpiece Guernica. Now leave the well-trodden thoroughfares of Madrid behind and head to the neighbourhood of Malasaña, in the north-west of the capital. A maze of small, narrow streets lined with cafes, bars and boutiques awaits. Roam around this labyrinth overflowing with charm and open to alternative ideas as well as a certain spirit of resistance. Could this be a nod to the very name of the area, dedicated in honour of Manuela Malasaña, a young 17-year-old woman who was shot there by French troops during the popular uprising of 1808?

History likes to repeat itself and as you reach Calle del Pez, you come across a young woman with books in her hand. This is After Julia, a statue created by Antonio Santín and unveiled in 2003. Besides the bronze's attractive looks, the sculpture is a tribute to the first woman who dared to defy the ban on studying at university in the 19th century.

The Calle del Pez, or Fish Street, has been around since the 17th century and it tells the tale of another young woman who rebelled against authority. To start with, a father bought a piece of land to build a house and on the original site, there was a pond full of fish. However, they all died because of the construction work, except one, rescued by Blanca Colonel, the daughter of the new owner. Despite her lavish care and attention, the surviving fish also perished. In an attempt to console her, the father had a fish carved in the stone facade, which can still be seen at number 24. And this is the fish that gave the street its name today. Over the centuries, the atmosphere has changed and life here is now all about partying, meeting up with friends and unbridled cultural and artistic expression.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

In the realm of lowbrow art

To understand the rich cultural heritage and special character of Malasaña, take yourself off to La Fiambrera art gallery. The interior, which looks like a simple shop, has plenty of surprises in store for you. Start on the ground floor: all the walls are covered from floor to ceiling with illustrations, adverts, graffiti and comic art with often funny, sometimes ironic and even caustic overtones. You are in the realm of lowbrow art or pop surrealism. Stroll around, drawn from one exhibit to another and yet another, then go down to the gallery's vaulted basement. The simple stone surroundings show off works by international artists to their very best: with works by the likes of North American Danny Heller, Argentinian Dr. Alderete and local boy, Joaquín Rodríguez, the collection is as colourful as it is cosmopolitan. When your pop art extravaganza comes to an end, stop by the gallery shop. There you will find books, original decorative items and posters to take home as a fitting souvenir of this out-of-the-ordinary visit. And if you are feeling peckish, order a cup of coffee and a delicious homemade pastry.

La Fiambrera art gallery
Calle del Pez, 7
Madrid
Spain
+34 917 04 60 30
https://www.lafiambrera.net/en/

A delight for the senses Madrid-style

All this artistic exploration is hungry work indeed. To eat like the locals, opt for Pez Tortilla, a restaurant you will find at 36 Calle del Pez. It is one of the favourite places of Malasaña residents. And when you read the menu, you will immediately understand that it was well worth the wait: tortillas or Spanish omelettes with mozzarella, sun-dried tomatoes and basil – a fabulous Spanish-Italian combo, or what about with brie and truffles or even mackerel…? Whether you choose a classic or novel version, these specialities are all creamy, set just the way you like them and very tasty. If you fancy, you can wash your tortilla down with a beer from the restaurant's exacting and international selection.

To discover a different type of ambiance, go back to the start of the street. At Amargo, in its subdued decor with light brickwork and velvet furniture, you will enjoy a sophisticated and bountiful cuisine. Tuna tataki with diced tomatoes and white garlic or beef with porcini mushrooms, you have the choice of dishes from the land and sea. The menu also ensures that there is always a vegan option on offer. Every weekend, the restaurant invites musicians to come and perform, providing a musical side order to your dinner.

From the restaurant, you are only a few doors away from Zombie Bar with its off-beat atmosphere and focus on comic book art. The golden rule here is never take yourself seriously, just like the menus which are set out like comic books or the bill which arrives at your table in an old VHS video cassette box. Here, you will meet Malasaña regulars: DJs, avant-garde musicians, photographers, designers, artists in the making, hipsters... These Zombie Bar aficionados meet up, chat and put the world to rights in a buzz of excitement that lasts until the small hours. Because here, as elsewhere in Malasaña, life is lived day and night to the beat of music, bars and friendly encounters.

content.title: Hola Coffee, coffee as ultimate relaxation

introduction.small: The Spanish capital boasts a new hotspot for caffeine addicts: Hola Coffee makes no fuss and bets everything on quality.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hola Coffee, coffee as ultimate relaxation

paragraphs.text:
Between two art galleries and only a few steps away from the Reina Sofia Museum in the Lavapiés neighbourhood, Hola Coffee is a true haven of rest where you will feel right at home. Clear colours, raw walls and plants give off a soothing feeling that explains why regulars come in numbers.

However, the main attraction remains sheer product quality over any other consideration: coffee beans are responsibly and independently farmed, and then roasted on the premises by the baristas. Expressos, lattes or ice coffees will satisfy all your needs.

For puckish customers, and at any time, savoury and sweet snacks are available, from avocado toasts served with gravlax, to homemade cookies and cakes.

Get a book or engage in conversations with your neighbours. The delicate smell of your drink will put the finishing touch to the most relaxed of your Madrid breaks.

Hola Coffee

28012 Madrid

+34 910 568 263

hola.coffee/

content.title: Arallo Madrid, flavours between soil and sea

introduction.small: Only a few steps away from the Prado, Arallo Madrid showcases a counter cuisine, fusing Andalusia and Asia in a vintage and trendy decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arallo Madrid, flavours between soil and sea

paragraphs.text:
Coolness is key at Arallo Madrid, in the heart of the Spanish capital. The industrial-style decoration catches the eye from the second you step in. With subdued light and raw concrete lights, everything feels somehow rough around the edges there. Seating at the bar on a high wooden stool, you will be able to snack on a few appetizers and have a look at how dishes are being prepared in the open kitchen. The restaurant offers a menu that blends Galician gastronomy with exotic products and Asian flavours. Moreover, a distinction is being made with, on one side of the menu, ground-farmed animals like grilled prime rib and a colourful “Indi” pizza, and seafood on the other. Mussels with a vaporous green mousse or salmon with crispy vegetables in vinegar being only some of the key dishes. A very sweet getaway amid chic and trendy Madrid.

Arallo Madrid

28004 Madrid

www.arallotaberna.com/madrid/

content.title: Urso Hotel and Spa, fusing old and new

introduction.small: Amid the elegant Chamberí district, Urso Hotel & Spa has established itself as the new leading five star in Madrid.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Urso Hotel and Spa, fusing old and new

paragraphs.text:
In a former 20th-century palace restored in a neoclassical style, Urso Hotel & Spa reveals a perfect combination of traditional and new Madrid. Typical in Spain, its 1900s architecture blends with stylish and contemporary decor. The large marble staircase and stained-glass windows are original, when the large windows letting natural light in, the oak flooring in the bedrooms and modern furniture all add a more contemporary feel to the premises.
From your bedroom's private terrace, you will enjoy the quietness of the chic Chamberí district, away from touristic areas yet only a few minutes away by foot from the city's major spots. Enjoy the spa, located in the hotel's basement, for a very intimate moment, as well as the wooden swimming pool. Body and skin care are also available, with unusual treatments like diamond powder exfoliation. A perfect landing spot for a high-end stay in Madrid.

content.title: Barceló Torre de Madrid, on the cutting edge of design

introduction.small: Barceló Torre de Madrid enjoys an ideal location in Madrid's most emblematic building, on top of a particularly refined decoration.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Barceló Torre de Madrid, on the cutting edge of design

paragraphs.text:
This very trendy hotel takes up the first nine floors of the Torre Madrid, one of the highest buildings in Spain. Madrid designer Jaime Hayón strove to create cool interiors, using clear tones on the walls and adding his personal touch here and there for an element of fun and surprise: for instance, the sculpture of a stripped bear cub towers over the ground floor. You will also make the best of the huge chrome indoor swimming pool to cool off during Madrid's heat waves. The 258 rooms add refinement to modernity. They all showcase solid wood floors and the designer's signature "monkey table". Furthermore, they all offer spectacular views of the city, great vantage point to admire the sunset over the entire region.
If you feel hungry, head to the Somos restaurant on the second floor of the hotel. Light comes through huge picture windows, as the establishment offers a varied menu - carefully elaborated by nutritionist and food designer Vanessa Losada - that has rapidly become a fancy Madrid hallmark. A pure delight!

28008 Madrid

content.title: Mercado de Motores, the market with a thousand and one finds

introduction.small: You must go to the Mercado de Motores, in the Delicias district, which will lead you to good memories of your stay in Madrid.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mercado de Motores, the market with a thousand and one finds

paragraphs.text:
On the second weekend of every month, make sure you go to this unique little market, Mercado de Motores, and wander among wagons and locomotives of the 19th century. Installed in the former Delicias train station, this market welcomes more than 200 craftsmen, designers, and antique dealers of all kinds who present their productions or show off their latest finds. Unearth your treasure in the middle of old bicycles, retro furniture, vintage clothes and second-hand objects.

Various food stands offer a number of tapas for a break while listening to local musicians play their Catalan repertoire live in an atmosphere as festive as it is welcoming. A one-of-a-kind place that will make you want to stay all day (and indeed the market is open until 10 p.m.). Since you are not far away, make a detour to the Railway Museum, a place dear to model collectors, where the most curious can learn everything about the world of railways.

Mercado de Motores

content.title: Media Racíon, the trendy Spanish gastronomic destination

introduction.small: Created by Fernando Cuenllas, Media Ración opens its doors at the Hotel Urso and goes all out with its recipes in local colours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Media Racíon, the trendy Spanish gastronomic destination

paragraphs.text:
In a place full of conviviality, wood and glass blend perfectly with leather and steel touches at this concept restaurant invented by Fernando Cuenllas. Here is a bar but also a shop, with walls covered with delicatessen products and bottles of wine. Media Ración-translated as 'small portion'- adopts a spirit of sharing, not to reign yourself in, but to allow you to taste everything on the menu.

Everyone can enjoy different typical dishes, which make the reputation of the Spanish capital. On the savoury side, choose between a foie gras mi-cuit and its brioche bun, a beef tenderloin with vegetables and chimichurri sauce, grilled hake with purple carrots, not to mention local cheese and charcuterie platters. On the sweet side, savour toasted vanilla cream, a millefeuille or a lemon tart. If you are an oenophile, you will not be disappointed by the selection of great wines that Fernando Cuenllas has chosen.

content.title: High-end tapas at La Castela

introduction.small: A short walk from Parque del Retiro, La Castela offers a culinary rediscovery of local tapas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: High-end tapas at La Castela

paragraphs.text:
Since 1929, La Castela has maintained the profile of an old tavern of yesteryear with its zinc counter, stuccoed kitchen shelves and suspended mirrors, down to one detail-the famous tapas. Here you will discover updated and upscale versions of these traditional Spanish dishes, attracting a fine crowd of food lovers – including Barack and Michelle Obama. In a typical Madrid atmosphere of tapas bars in the region, sit at the counter or in the back room to enjoy your meal.

Order some of these delicious tapas with your drinks. You will not be able to do without cured beef ham à la León, salted tuna fillets with almonds, and giant red shrimp croquetes, while sipping a nice glass of Castilian wine. For the most insatiable among you, the menu also offers a wide selection of fish and meat.

content.title: One Shot Prado 23, in the shadow of the masters

introduction.small: The combination of contemporary style and art in a superbly located 42-room hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: One Shot Prado 23, in the shadow of the masters

paragraphs.text:
Does being near the Prado Museum have an effect on the hotel? Has proximity to the paintings of the great masters encouraged the owners to celebrate aesthetics and design? One Shot Prado 23 has put art at the heart of its approach. The hotel has showcased its competitive prices amid a popular and trendy neighbourhood, and yet never forgets to pay great attention to the decor.

Each piece is carefully selected to fit in with a contemporary context that gives pride of place to white walls and light wood with touches of colour. The architectural firm Las2Mercedes has decorated each of the 42 rooms in this hotel with vintage-inspired pieces and also maximum modern comfort, from the rain shower to a Touch Panel linking laptop to TV. content.title: Sala de despiece, a butcher break

introduction.small: ‘Sala de despiece' means, literally, the cutting room. This restaurant, acclaimed for its top ingredients, is also an old-style butcher.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sala de despiece, a butcher break

paragraphs.text:
On the ceiling, a colourful checkerboard and metal rails decorated with butcher hooks. Yet, gourmets will only have eyes for the menu. The handwritten, always-changing menu features the freshest products: oysters, lobster, crab and also Spanish cheese, Iberian ham, sirloin and other cuts share the limelight. Whether the beef is raw, served as ceviche, cooked a la plancha, or a la chalaca like in Peru, preparations are meticulous, and ingredients carefully chosen to delight even the most demanding of gourmets. The exact weight of the portions of beef are written down, just like in the old days. And, the restaurant doesn't do anything by halves: you eat on red and white butcher paper. The taste of authenticity in a trendy setting.

content.title: The Ritz Madrid and its enchanting gardens

introduction.small: Pretend you're the ‘Last Tycoon' wandering through the enchanting gardens of the palace, a Fitzgerald novel in hand.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Ritz Madrid and its enchanting gardens

paragraphs.text:
At the dawn of the 20th century, King Alfonso XIII wanted to transform Madrid, at the time a small provincial town, into a European capital of the first order.

Since opening in 1910, the Ritz has supported this change in status, receiving the European aristocracy and the biggest celebrities on the planet, with Nelson Mandela, Salvador Dalí, and Madonna numbering among its storied clientele. Today, the hotel's grandiloquent style is a bit dated but this only adds to its charm.

Antique ornaments and centuries-old tapestries abound in the 154 rooms, which are spacious and yet intimate, with embroidered bed linens and panoramic balconies. The gorgeous gardens are the highlight of the hotel. Escape from the frenetic pace of the city for a bit of tranquillity in a sea of green, barely disturbed by the pianist's soft playing…

For your moments of relaxation, the Bodyna Spa's heated pool and Jacuzzi area, as well as the Turkish steam bath are at your disposal. And for those who like to commune with nature, the rooms on the fourth floor looking out onto the park have the most inspiring views.

content.title: Dine in the sky at the Palacio de Cibeles

introduction.small: The cuisine of Adolfo Muñoz emphasises local products and natural flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dine in the sky at the Palacio de Cibeles

paragraphs.text:
The Palacio de Cibeles serves carefully prepared local cuisine that is very likely to leave you satisfied. The restaurant is located on the rooftop of the wonderful, fully renovated Madrid city hall, which, from an altitude of 70 m, dominates the Castellana. On summer evenings, the terrace is a must. Chef Adolfo Muñoz, from Toledo, is the son of fruit and vegetable growers and, as such, he is a strong supporter of local products and their unadulterated flavours – to the point when he sometimes barely salts dishes. At the head of a small food empire (several restaurants, a cooking and wine school, a bakery, a pastry shop, and Adolfo Colección, an upscale shop dedicated to gourmet food), Muñoz also owns vineyards on the outskirts of Toledo (El Cigarral) and an olive grove. Which you can sense while browsing the Palacio de Cibeles wine list, boasting some 120 different vintages.

content.title: A day at the Prado

introduction.small: Bosch, Rubens, El Greco, Velázquez, Goya, Cranach: this is one of the most impressive art collections in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A day at the Prado

paragraphs.text:
Housed in a neoclassical building designed by Juan de Villanueva in 1785, the Prado Museum, open to the public since 1819, has one of the most impressive art collections in the world. There are more than 7,800 pieces in the permanent collection.

Among the 1,300 works on display are priceless treasures of the 16th to the 19th centuries, including a wide panorama of Flemish, Spanish, French, Italian, and German paintings, collected by the Habsburgs and the Bourbons and passed on to the Spanish state after the fall of Elizabeth II of Spain in 1868.

Immerse yourself in the beauty of these masterpieces by Titian, Caravaggio, Bosch, Rubens, Brueghel the Elder, Rembrandt, Poussin, Watteau, Boucher, Dürer, Cranach, and Gainsborough. These are grouped around the Spanish art collection, which contains 3,700 works, including the most comprehensive collections of El Greco, Velázquez, and Goya. In its 42,000 square metres, the Prado also houses collections of prints and drawings, over a thousand sculptures, and countless works of art.

Nacional del Prado Museum
Paseo del Prado
28014 Madrid

+34 913 302 800

https://www.museodelprado.es/en

content.title: Immerse yourself in art history at the Thyssen-Bornemisza

introduction.small: From Italian primitives to pop art, the breadth of artistic movements and trends represented in this collection is astounding.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Immerse yourself in art history at the Thyssen-Bornemisza

paragraphs.text:
With a rich collection of over 1,600 works, the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum covers a period from the 13th century to the 20th century. Rather than being exhaustive, the institution, which is just around the corner from the Prado, celebrates several major art movements: the Renaissance, with paintings by Titian, Caravaggio, and the Baroque period, and Rococo and Pop Art.

Usually neglected by Madrid's public museums, Impressionism, Fauvism, and German Expressionism are also present. The fruit of the expert taste of two generations of Thyssens, it is thanks to Baron Hans Heinrich von Thyssen-Bornemisza that the collection includes 20th century works, like those of Degas, Mondrian, Picasso, and Léger.

The Baron sold part of the collection of his residence in Lugano to the Spanish State in 1992, for a mere $400 million. Be sure to arrive early: the museum is even more popular than the Prado.

Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum

+34 917 911 370

https://www.museothyssen.org/en

content.title: El Club Allard: excellent and very select

introduction.small: Chef Diego Guerrero has turned this former club into a temple of Spanish gourmet cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Club Allard: excellent and very select

paragraphs.text:
Installed in the Casa Gallardo, a magnificent Modernist building built in 1908 by architect Federico Arias Rey, the El Club Allard was once a very exclusive club. Since 2003, it has become a temple of Spanish gastronomy.

To seduce you, chef José Carlos, who learnt his trade at some of the best national and international restaurants and now runs the place, lays on creative and highly technical cuisine combined in two different menus, "Gourmet" and "Spring", changed every morning depending on the availability of seasonal products. Pricing remains fairly affordable for that quality of gastronomy.

Be forewarned: because it is listed as a heritage building, there is no restaurant sign outside. Very hip, this popular place regularly hosts art exhibitions, literary awards, and the Enrique Ponce bullfighter prize.

Started by two brothers from Asturias, Nino and Santi Redruello, the Gabinoteca is a tapas hangout and a cocktail bar on two levels that hosts a trendy crowd. The emphasis here is on the quality of ingredients. The latter can be selected in the most unusual manner: the list actually points towards your particular state of mind following a personality test. The desserts are original: a chocolate fondant served with strawberries, vanilla ice cream and melting hot chocolate, skilfully served in a bike shape. content.title: Madrid's markets

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Madrid's markets

The San Miguel Market is known for its wonderful food stalls and excellent but affordable tapas bars. Near the Plaza Mayor, the site his hidden by this incredible early-20th-century architecture, blending glass, iron and ceramics. Furiously animated, this is a fantastic place if you crave a snack, seated at one of the big communal tables, a glass of wine in hand.

The market of San Antón, renovated in 2002, stands on three floors in the heart of the city's bohemian district. The first level is devoted to cold meats and organic fruits and vegetables. The second sells wine and various specialties to take away. The third floor is the lovely terrace restaurant, San Antón Cocina, open for lunch. A more traditional market, San Antón, is considerably cheaper than San Miguel.

content.title: Madrid in its districts and barrios

introduction.small: Historic Centro, sophisticated Salamanca, trendy Chueca, cultural Recoletos, lyrical Lavapiés, and La Latina, the showcase of bodegas... all express Madrid's vitality.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Madrid in its districts and barrios

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Madrid, the Centro area is home to some of the most spectacular monuments. This is where you will find the Plaza Mayor, the busy flea market of El Rastro, and Puerta del Sol. Lose yourself in the maze of cobbled streets of Old Madrid and reassemble its history.

Salamanca is another essential area, with its designer shops, upscale restaurants, and sophisticated night-life. Chueca is the trendiest district of Madrid, with its unusual boutiques, casual restaurants, and hipster haunts for night owls.

Recoletos is the cultural quarter, home to the most iconic art museums of the capital. Finally, Lavapiés is where the best art galleries are, plus the largest theatres and the most beautiful concert halls. La Latina, meanwhile, is the mecca of tapas bars and bistros.

content.title: La Plaza de Toros de las Ventas: a Republican monument

introduction.small: The verses of Federico García Lorca's Llanto dresses the Plaza de Toros las Ventas, a neo-Moorish style bullring inaugurated by the Republicans.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Plaza de Toros de las Ventas: a Republican monument

paragraphs.text:
On August 11, 1934, in Manzanares, the bull Granadino injured the bullfighter Ignacio Sánchez Mejías. Gangrene set in, and he died in hospital on August 13.

His friend Federico García Lorca then wrote ‘Llanto por la muerte de Ignacio Sánchez Mejías' (‘Weeping for the Death of Ignacio Sánchez Mejías'). The first public reading was held in Madrid on November 4. The poem evokes the fate of one who was a Sevilliano, bullfighter, music lover, lover of life, intellectual, and playwright.

Think back to the last verses: 'It will be born long before, if ever born / An Andalusian so clear, so full of adventures / I sing his elegance with words that moan / And I remember a sad breeze in the olive trees.' They will ring with a special brightness when you tread down the earthenware tiles of the Plaza de Toros las Ventas del Espiritu de Santo, which was inaugurated in October 1934 and is now a listed building.

La Plaza de Toros de las Ventas

28028 Madrid

content.title: Luzi Bombón: upscale design brasserie

introduction.small: Luzi Bombón is both a retro-chic brasserie and a trendy nightspot on the Castellana. It's especially hopping on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday nights.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Luzi Bombón: upscale design brasserie

The latest creation of Grupo Tragaluz, the Luzi Bombón made a strong impression at the time of its appearance on the Madrid night scene.

With its retro interior composed of 1950s fabrics, polished concrete floors, and panelled walls, the restaurant, decorated by the highly rated Spanish designer Sandra Tarruella, looks like it stepped out of the pages of the English magazine, Wallpaper. In terms of food, too, the establishment is very fashion-forward.

The menu, inspired by French brasserie fare, serves tapas like wood-oven piquillo pimentos and Mediterranean specialities along with raw oysters and delicious Spanish dishes made with rice. As the night progresses, the Luzi Bombón is transformed into a party venue, where the city's best DJs will make you dance until the first light of dawn.

content.title: Plaza Mayor, the Madrid of the Habsburgs

introduction.small: The baroque Plaza Mayor, finished in 1619, was the privileged theatre of the rich history of Habsburg Spain. A custom-ordered architectural dream, it was commissioned by Philip II.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plaza Mayor, the Madrid of the Habsburgs

paragraphs.text:
Madrid's main square since the 16th century, the Plaza Mayor's strongest features are its red arcades, its equestrian statue of Philip III, and the Casa de la Panaderia, recognisable by the frescoes that decorate its facade.

Three engineering architects built this stunning monument. In the late 16th century, Philip II commissioned Juan de Herrera, the hidalgo of the architectural style that bears his name – the strict 'herrerian' style characterised by straight and severe lines – to draw up the plans for the Plaza. Then Juan Gómez de Mora, of much more baroque sensibility, created the square. Finally, after its partial destruction as a result of a fire, the famous neoclassical architect Juan de Villanueva gave it its present appearance. This is where the fires of the Inquisition were stoked, and corridas, beatifications, and coronations took place.

Today, it is a quiet square, populated by terraces, where you will dream, with delight, of swordsmen…

content.title: Romanticism at the Teatro Real

introduction.small: Italian opera, Spanish works, and contemporary creations, at one of the most prestigious opera houses in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Romanticism at the Teatro Real

paragraphs.text:
The building was opened November 19, 1850 by Queen Isabel II with an opera in four acts by Gaetano Donizetti, The Favourite, which French-language libretto magnified Leonara, mistress of King Alfonso XI de Castile. The neoclassical Teatro Real had a prestigious run until 1925. It hosted the greatest Spanish artists of its time (Ruperto Chapi, Tomás Bretón, Emilio Serrano), alongside Verdi, Strauss, and Saint-Saëns, and also staged works by Meyerbeer, Bellini, Rossini, and Wagner.

After many adventures (during the 1920s, the theatre was closed down because damages caused by the excavation for the Madrid metro), it was rehabilitated as the official state opera house in 1997, regaining its former magnificence. The best thing, of course, is to buy a ticket and attend a performance, but you can also just have a tour. The views of the Royal Palace, Almudena Cathedral, and the gardens of the Plaza de Oriente are spectacular. Unless you would rather try its starred-ceiling restaurant, decorated by Pascua Ortega, or the Palacio cafe.

introduction.small: If you want to dress like a Castillian nobleman, Capa Seseña is the place to go.

In 1901, the legendary cape was a best-seller (traditionally stitched by hand by Santos Seseña Rojas), as its fluid elegance was the tell-tale sign of a true gentleman.

More comfortable than an overcoat, Seseña capes have wrapped Picasso, Buñuel, Hemingway, Fellini, Mastroianni, Hillary Clinton, Michael Jackson, Bruce Springsteen, Catherine Deneuve, Jane Fonda, and, of course, King Juan Carlos. Since taking over the reins of the family business small in size but more than a century old Marco Seseña has revived the August house by creating stylish models for women in collaboration with Marina Conde, the head designer of La Condesa.

In 2015, Seseña launched a new, shorter-cut line for the modern man. Muy elegante!

content.title: The shimmering silks of the Lázaro Galdiano Museum

introduction.small: The Lázaro Galdiano Museum, now public, contains a wonderfully rich collection of art—from Bosch to Goya—and crafts, including fabrics.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The shimmering silks of the Lázaro Galdiano Museum

paragraphs.text:
The Lázaro Galdiano Museum houses a staggering collection of Hispanic-Muslim fabrics. To which is added a collection of Francisco Goya paintings, drawings, and engravings, as well as numerous works by Hieronymus Bosch, Cranach the Elder, El Greco, and Bartolomé Esteban Murillo, exploring the space between allegories and dreams. Make time for the collection's spectacular 'school of Bosch' dreamscape Visio Tnugdali (1520-1530). Housed within the walls of the magnificent neo-Renaissance 'palacio' of Parque Florida in the Salamanca district, the museum offers a magnificent collection of encyclopaedic range. You will also be able to marvel at rare manuscripts from medieval times. Once one of the world's largest private collections of Spanish art, it is now owned by the state.

The winter garden of this former socialite club remains the pinnacle of the hotel, with its Belle Époque stained-glass dome.

It offers 470 rooms and suites spread over six floors, and several restaurants, including the landmark Rotonda, plus bars, a beauty salon, and a fitness room. This enormous and iconic Art Deco ocean liner of a hotel was commissioned by King Alfonso XIII in 1912.

content.title: La Venencia: Andalusia in a glass

introduction.small: Madrid's historic tavern, serving Fino and oloroso sherries in a warm and naturally very English ambience.

Enter La Venencia and travel back in time in an authentic bodega. Surrounded by old barrels and traditional woodwork, start your oenological experience with dry sherry, called Fino, before moving onto the heavier wines, such as the olorosos – to be enjoyed in moderation.

For sweeter wines, try Pedro Ximenez or Moscatel sherries. To accompany these nectars, the establishment offers a concise but oh so effective menu of tempting tapas like serrano jamón, marinated olives in garlic and petits fours in bleu cheese.

content.title: The necropolis of kings in El Escorial

introduction.small: Pantheon of Spanish kings, the monastery of San Lorenzo del Escorial at the foot of the Sierra de Guadarrama, north of Madrid, is also the symbol of the great Spanish Golden Age.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The necropolis of kings in El Escorial

paragraphs.text:
The Monastery of San Lorenzo del Escorial, commonly known as 'El Escorial', was the political centre of an empire under the direction of a mystic king, Philip II. Its pantheon is the last residence of Spanish grandees: Charles V, Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire and the majority of his descendants, the kings of Spain from the houses of Austria and the Bourbons. It still houses the royal palace of the Habsburgs, a magnificent art gallery, a gigantic humanist library (45,000 volumes), a basilica, and French gardens.

Commissioned by Philip II, the monastery was completed under the direction of the architect Juan de Herrera, in full, severe, herreriano Renaissance style. A UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1984, El Escorial is representative of Flemish architecture, with its slate roofs and pointed towers. The palace-monastery, a symbol of the famous Spanish Golden Age (between the 16th and 17th centuries), is 50 minutes away from Madrid by car, bus or train from the Atocha station.

content.title: The fallen angel in Buen Retiro Park

introduction.small: Buen Retiro Park is a lush oasis of more than 15,000 trees over 125 hectares in the heart of the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The fallen angel in Buen Retiro Park

paragraphs.text:
Madrid has several beautiful parks. The iconic Parque del Buen Retiro, literally 'Park of the Pleasant Retreat', is the most famous. Formerly a royal garden, it has been open to the public since the 1860s, and is a favourite walking, jogging, and picnicking destination for Madrileños during the day and on weekends. There are 12 kiosks where you can have a drink, a lovely lake if you want to go for a canoe paddle, and remarkable fountains to cool off next to. In the French flowerbed, it also collects the famous bald cypress that Cortes brought back from Mexico.

If you have a fondness for the occult, you will not want to miss Ricardo Bellver's Fountain of the Fallen Angel, the world's only public monument depicting Satan. Relax in the Garden of Perennials, the Andalusian gardens of Cecilio Rodriguez, those of architect Herrero Palacios, or in the fabulous rose garden. Note the romantic Crystal Palace, created to accommodate specimens of exotic plants during the 1887 Exhibition of the Philippine Islands.

Located in the El Columpio restaurant of the Chamberí district, the Madrid pioneer of the brunch concept has become a classic and still remains, despite several relocations, one of the very best of its kind in the Spanish capital. The atmosphere is radically cosmopolitan and the menu very Mediterranean. The feeling is that of a trendy nightclub in the basement lounge bar, where a DJ spins records on weekends.

An institution since 1966, the house features specials that include the couscous cheeseburger and brownie with mozzarella, as well as more classic brunch fare: genuine fluffy pancakes, scrambled eggs with herbs, and fresh fruit salads, all served in hearty portions that make it difficult to finish one's plate. content.title: The Royal Palace: the Madrid of the Bourbons

introduction.small: The decorations and collections of the Royal Palace of Madrid symbolise the splendour and magnificence of the kingdom.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Royal Palace: the Madrid of the Bourbons

paragraphs.text:
This magnificent palace of granite and white limestone is the official residence of the king of Spain. Located on the Plaza de Oriente, in the heart of the Spanish capital, it is today only used for ceremonial purposes.

Built between 1738 and 1755 by the Italian Giovanni Battista Sachetti under the orders of Philip V, this building of neoclassical architecture was lavishly decorated by artists like Goya (a portrait of the Infante Carlos of Spain, known as Charles V), Vélazquez (attached to the king's house for 20 ducats a month), El Greco, Rubens, Tiepolo (frescoes on the ceiling of the throne room), Mengs, and Caravaggio.

The palace also houses various collections of great importance including: the Royal Armoury, which contains weapons and armour dating back to the 13th century; the largest Stradivarius collection in the world; and carpets, porcelain (the Buen Retiro Manufacture in the porcelain room), and furniture.

content.title: Puerta del Sol: under Goya's brush

introduction.small: Symbol of the Dos de Mayo, Puerta del Sol is the kilometre zero of all Spanish roads.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Puerta del Sol: under Goya's brush

paragraphs.text:
Everything starts at the Puerta del Sol: not just all Spanish roads but also the uprising the people of Madrid against the occupying French forces on May 2, 1808, as immortalised by Goya (visible in the Prado), which marks the beginning of the Spanish war of independence. The painting Dos de Mayo called in English The Second of May 1808 or The Charge of the Mamelukes forms a diptych with Tres de Mayo (The Third of May 1808), which describes the execution of insurgents by the French troops.

Now closed to traffic, Puerta del Sol lost the sundial that gave it its name but retains the famous neon sign for Tio Pepe sherry and the giant sculpture by Antonio Navarro Santafe (1906-1983). It also remains a historic meeting place, where people gather to protest for democracy. It's also the ideal place to commence your perambulations through the narrow, winding streets of the old town.

content.title: The Spaniard art scene goes electric at CaixaForum

introduction.small: A centre of art and contemporary culture in a former power station.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Spaniard art scene goes electric at CaixaForum

paragraphs.text:
A socio-cultural centre with a mandate to democratise access to art, the CaixaForum opened in 2008 and is funded by a charitable foundation.

Located in the heart of Madrid in a former power station, the Central Eléctrica del Medioda was audaciously converted by Swiss architects Herzog & de Meuron. The site is among the few structures of the industrial era still standing, and now stands as one of the city symbols.

Conceived as a space for debate, seminars and lectures are held regularly in its auditorium. CaixaForum is also as a modern and contemporary art exhibition space, encompassing two floors and showing the private collection (more than 600 works) of the La Caixa Bank.

Focal points are the vegetation wall designed by the French botanist Patrick Blanc using no less than 15,000 plants, and the huge central staircase, which leads to a restaurant and café on the 7th floor.

content.title: The triumph of the Minotaur at Museo ICO

introduction.small: One of only five museums in the world with a complete set of Picasso's ‘Vollard Suite' of 100 etchings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The triumph of the Minotaur at Museo ICO

paragraphs.text:
The Museo Colecciones ICO (Instituto de Crédito Oficial) houses works by the greatest names in Spanish sculpture and painting of the 20th century, including Miró, Dalí, Gaudi, Tàpies, Solano, Chillida, and Barceló.

Above all, however, like the National Gallery in Washington, the MOMA, the Picasso Museum in Paris, and the British Museum, it has its own complete set of 'Vollard Suite' variations on the theme of the minotaur, by Pablo Picasso. These 100 etchings were the basis of Guernica (where the figure of the Minotaur is also present). The series is named after the art dealer Ambroise Vollard, (who happened to be Picasso's first art dealer) with whom Picasso exchanged them for a Renoir and a Cézanne.

310 complete sets were produced from the 100 original plates. Many of these were sold upon the death of Vollard to another dealer, Henry Petiet. The rest were scattered far and wide…

content.title: Diversity itself is cultivated in the Real Jardín Botánico

introduction.small: Lush green wonders abound in this garden gem of eight hectares, near the Prado Museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Diversity itself is cultivated in the Real Jardín Botánico

paragraphs.text:
On its three staggered terraces, reconfigured between 1785 and 1789 by Juan de Villanueva, the architect of the Prado, the Royal Botanical Gardens of Madrid (Real Jardín Botánico) has now roughly 5,000 plant varieties from Europe, the Americas, and the Pacific. As European expeditions went on, the site became a must in the realm of natural sciences. There are also statues and a number of small greenhouses packed into the eight-hectare park.

Property of the Higher Council of Scientific Research since 1939, it was declared an 'art garden' in 1942, before being abandoned. Finally renovated in 1981 by the landscape architect Leandro Silva Delgado (1930-2000), it's worth a visit not only for the spectacular plants and flowers, but also for the architecture and contemporary art exhibitions in the Villanueva pavilion.

content.title: Guernica at the Reina Sofia

introduction.small: A showcase of modern and contemporary art at the Reina Sofia, reconfigured in 2006 by architect Jean Nouvel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Guernica at the Reina Sofia

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 1992 by the King and Queen of Spain, this museum is mainly dedicated to Spanish art of the 20th and 21st centuries. The building is easy to recognise: it's a former Royal Hospital and now a historical monument, with three glass and steel elevators.

It was designed by architects José Luis Iñiguez de Onzoño and Antonio Vázquez de Castro, and an extension was added by Jean Nouvel. The museum now occupies more than 84,000 sqm and contains an extensive collection of works by Salvador Dalí, Juan Miró, and Pablo Picasso. The jewel of the collection is Picasso's Guernica (accompanied by its 45 preliminary sketches).

Commissioned by the Republican government for the Spanish pavilion of the 1937 Paris World Exhibition, the subject of this gigantic Cubist work is said to stem from Paul Éluard, following the April 26, 1937 bombing of the small village of Guernica by the Nazis and Italian Fascists. The painting was kept in the United States during the Franco years, and returned to Spain in 1981.

Museo nacional centro de arte Reina Sofia
Calle de Santa Isabel 52
28012 Madrid

+34 917 741 000

https://www.museoreinasofia.es/en

content.title: Arco de la Victoria: Madrid under the dictatorship

introduction.small: The Arco de la Victoria, built in 1956 to celebrate Franco's victory over the Republicans, is one of 86 symbols of the Franco dictatorship still present in the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arco de la Victoria: Madrid under the dictatorship

paragraphs.text:
Whether they are street names, monuments, or inscriptions, all participate in the glory of 'Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Caudillo de España por la gracia de Dios'. Today, there are still countless Francoist symbols in the schools and buildings of the Catholic Church, whose hierarchy was closely linked to the regime.

Despite the Historical Memory Law of 2007, which stated that 'the government will take appropriate measures to remove crests, badges, plaques, and other commemorative objects or references of exaltation, personal or collective, of the military uprising, of the civil war, and the repression by the dictatorship,' you will realise, during your walks through the city, that all have not gone away. As proof, this impressive 49-metre-high arch is just 800 meters from the President's residence. Democracy shall never forget the turmoil of the past.

Arco de la Victoria
Avenida de la Memoria 32
28040 Madrid
